make ground plaine euen better sowing bestowing seed good proportion sort vpon ground vvhich common husbandman v eth doe time called dusting time notwithstanding inhabitant beauce doe strictly stand vpon reason fatnesse ground take time howsoeuer shapeth hauing good assurance time whether continue faire turne rainie order common fashion breake clod rowler vvhich would doe well marble tough stiffe ground else may breake harrow well toothed sharppointed teeth yron good length howsoeuer must labour oft goe ouer may broken dust possible may remaine one clod vnbroken sowne yet certaine clodding arable ground shall know must done according nature soyle euer good shower raine first falleth seed sowne ground loose soft mould verie apt breake backside harrowes runne ouer land vvill sufficient earth hard binding shall take rowler wood marble great deale heauie indeed onely fit grassegrounds cornegrounds also teeth harrow sharpe teare vp earth much vvhere vvoodden rowler vvill serue shall take cloddingbeetles made purpose broad flat breake clod peeces raine may soften backharrowes runne ouer againe called sleighting well clodding wherefore clod well broken made plaine second earingthe second earing shall cut vp ground againe mid iune fat moist moneth september leane drie otherwise leane ground would quite dried vp burnt sunne neither would remaine therein anie vertue iuice aboue thing must obserue keepe order plowing ground may drie moist great store moisture maketh dirt mire much drinesse doth disaduantage husbandman amaine either plough cannot enter ground enter yet cannot breake small ynough turneth vp thicke broad clod earth sort afterward hard plow vp field againe certainely cannot done requisite earth hard wherefore ground hath beene plowed drought must haue rainie season found plowed afterward againe watered moistened may easily tilled yet approuedst husbandman france rich profession held earth neuer plowed drie long plow able run one ardor gotten worth three moister weather besides greater clod arise plowing thus drie weather greater store mould shall haue good aduantage graine neither anie thing difficult plow stay good season haue earth throughly wet next plowing great clod doe neuer arise clay ground apt breake anie moisture shortly second earing shall giue third earingthe third earing must light breaketh deepe two former earing finished must make ground euen smooth harrow presently shall middest october shall sow bestow seed vpon ground good proportion anie time encrease moone neuer decrease likewise better take opportunitie little raine following prouerbe sayth must sowe wheat myre barly dust reason tha wheat hard comming neere nature wood doth bud better sooner layd steepe mollified dyrt else feare pismire wheat sowne drie ground would become lord carrie away notwithstanding see raine somewhat long comming seeing time man power shall deferre sow especially dry ground corne sowne dry ground well harrowed couered doth enioy keepe without corrupting well garner follow anie raine seed vp day presuppose meane time husbandman hath let rest lye idle ground two yeares wherein intending sow wheat end may bring better crop furthermore seed time expired past eighteenth day nouember earth coldnes aire becommeth close shut rugged staring agast able well receiue seed cause thriue true cold place seed must bee sowne earlier hote place later whereupon commeth passe italie sowe beginning nouember v france temperate october cold place coastcountries kallends september rather sooner end root come may growne strong winterraine doe molest yee frost doe hurt notwithstanding time soeuer sowe seed must e diuers conueiances ouerthwart ground conduit carrie away water corne yet seedtime spoken wheat rie called wintercornes pea beanes pulse would bee sowne februarie beginning march oat barley end march beginning aprill sometime husbandman shall haue occasion reioice hope good successe sometime feare doubt euill successe seed reason variablenes time hee shall haue good hope seed hee see time inclined sweet mild violent shower vnto temperate e cessiue often shower mild shower resemble dew excessiue one doe moisten coole much like manner snow doe fall abo ndance become hard frost following thereupon snow letteth stayeth earth spending selfe exhalation vvasting fatnesse otherwise vapour would consumed also said snow making doe wash water little little earth vvith pure sweet liquor vvere scumme raine serueth make earth fat prouided presently vpon melting snow fall shower raine accompanied vvith haile lastly frost come proper due time forward burne young sprout late hurt verie much chap xii choice quantitie seed sowne wheat make seed ofthe chusing seed wheat industrious husbandman shall chuse full thicke heauie firme hard strong cannot paine broken betwixt teeth red colour bright cleane aboue yeare old maketh sauourie welltasted bread threshed choice culled eares fanning winnowing lyeth vppermost thickest massie growne fat ground cont arily seated wherein wheat sowne hill plaine moist drie yet contrarie seed bad place rather sowne good place seed good place sowne bad seed neuer good doth become worse degenerate easily sowne bad plot much speake onely wheat place graine vse fraunce shall vnderstand diuers kind thereof shall shewed hereafter sith name familiar country repeat vse amongst neighbour especially england first called wholestraw wheatsor wheat straw whole entire hauing anie hollownesse within wheat largest goodliest yeeldeth greatest store flowre yet pure white colour prospereth onely rich stiffe claygrounds must necessarily haue three earings sowne next vnto great pollard wheat hath aues vpon eares large wheat also prospereth likewise vpon stiffe claygrounds yet aske one earing loues sowne vpon peaseground whence pea reaped yeare next small pollard loues indifferent earth grauelly barren mixture must haue euer full three earings ograue wheat loueth anie wellmixt soyle grow either three earings one besowne pea reaped laxen wheat ioy anie soyle except stiffe clay burning sand prouided haue fully three earings well manured lastly chylter wheat like vnto flaxen wheat good sowe seedseed degen rate lay steepe water certaine houres afterward spread lay abroad somewhere shadow drie may readie rowle runne time cast earth meanes shall chuse fairest cornes shall stay behind bo tome water sowe grow within three foure day swimme aloft aboue water shall taken away worth thing sow best vse either seed hennes else grind may get euen quantitie meale flowre within sowing corne doe sprinkle ouer little water wherein haue beene infused houseleeke stamped seedes root wild cucumber end corne may eaten moules fieldmouse like vermine yet howsoeuer may practise france receiued generally amongst husbandman steepe corne water sowe much moisture cooleth drowneth kernell much nay farre practise thereof wellreputed husbandman suffer corne much washed sowne quantitie corne must sownehow much corn serue sowing shall measured rated according peece ground arpent fat ground part take foure bushel wheat reasonable fat ground take fiue leane take true must respect vnto countrey place sowne cold country place waterie also alwaies subiect snowes needfull sowe great deale hot country temperate drie place much cold snow doe corrupt great st part seed besides time well obserued disposition ayre autumne must sowe lesse thicke winter time approaching comming neere winter great deale againe rainie weather must sowe thicker drie weather yet england country much colder france two bushel wheat pea fully sowe acre foure bushel barly oates three bushel beanes proportion man need alter vpon anie occasion whatsoeuer chap xiii harrowing weeding corne presently seed bestowed ground must last worke harrow along crosse ouerthwart ake furrow furrow ouerthwart onely would done harrowes hauing yron teeth rather woodden one make corne settle deeper earth doe breake make fmall great deale better meanes doe couer corne earth requireth least thicknesse foure finger may faster rooted safer bird thus must let alone whole winter vpon spring true winter must neglect make draynes draught thereby carrie away water falleth great aboundance raine manner harrowing entire ground lye together leuell plaine vndistinguished land cast vp ridge land many country could mean harrowed ouerthwart therefore wheresoeuer ground lye land common mixt amongst neighbour shall euer harrow land directly vp downe full length land beginning furrowes first ascending vp ridge harrowes said woodden harrow best loose mould yron harrowes tough binding mould oxeharrowoxeh rrow bigge two horseharrowes hath euer yron teeth best roughest earth especially new broken vp swarths horseharrowes going oxeharrow following spring time come wheat hath taken good root must weed ground store weedes winter raine ranknesse earth selfe haue caused abound ouergrow corne newly put vp fe ches tame wild poppie cockle like hauing weeded good doe second time eare beginneth shoot corne proue faire cleane meane time must weed first rootes hurt may remaine couered laden earth may stand faster earth grow vpward second time weeding must bare much wheat shoot vp still would rot vpon earth bring forth nothing againe second weeding shall stirre make euen ground little corne may close fast couered oot would cause die also rot away bringing forth nothing worke dutie small weight moment much oftentimes corne choaked weedes bowed earth much loftinesse taking opportunitie beating wind raine moreouer must abashed greater part eares proue emptie without hauing anie thing come perfection ripenesse againe good corne accompanied fetch darnell weedes bread onely made vnpleasant lesse sauourie wholesome discoloured also commeth one halfe good corne mingled filthie weedes insomuch three load corne winnowing doe yeeld two pure cleane corne worse field seedes scattered doe bring forth halfe much charged nothing well cleansed winnowed corne chap xiiii mowing shearing last labour toylethe last labour whole yeare going taken mowing cutting downe corne must attended becommeth ripe appeare turning colour light yellow throughout part alike graine altogether hardened turned red may grow thicker weathering barne rather standing field certaine cut downe good due season grow bigger encrease afterward whereas otherwise stay mowing shearing downe till throughly drie greatest part corne fall ground shearing become pray bird beast happen anie violent storme whirlewind lay flat earth must time make choice wane moone betwixt moone moone cut downe corne thereinthe time cut downe corne would haue corne keepe well best houre breake day full deaw manner shearing either cut middest straw end may haue stubblestubble couer countrey house also heat ouen bake bread country vnprouided wood beauce else cut within foot ground greater prouision strawstraw serue afterward make matsmats bed litter horse cattell yet greatest profit imploy making mat vse behoofe householder chamber remaineth shall either cut downe sickle hedgingbills made fast end great staffe make fire withall winter time else shall burned field themselues make dung mean raine falling thereupon ground especially sandie standing stiffe potter clay haue strong mould although french manner shearing wheat rie graines difference yet country vse sheare sunne risen time corne drie holding doubtlesse probable binding corne together sheaues whilest wet deaw vpon doth either rot make mildew quickly stubble much better mowe downe sythes cut vp sicklessythes sickle may goe neerer ground also saue much labour worke sooner better corne cut shall gathered together made sheaues led carried barne farmer must seated sufficient high place may receiue wind somewhat readily yet would haue wind commeth able goe house garden besides annoyance small chaffe would worke eye people perceiue would furthermore hurt much annoy garden sticking leaues hearbes tree also fruit autumne would drie make apt easie burnt heat sunne chap xv threshing corne last labour husbandman remaineth nothing thresh corneto thresh corne sow againe store vp lay aside garner sooner till three month passed haruest although corne gathered full ripenesse yet still goeth forward perfection lyeth barne gascoines notwithstanding fearing corne left long sheaues onely take great heat grow full butterfly mothes small wo me wont spoile cause sheaues dried three whole day sunne field mowen afterward thresh place carrying lastly corne threshed garner mean stand need barnes carrie sheaues keepe also custome vsed ireland spaine island neere vnto spaine cannot commend husbandrie certaine except corne may take kindly sweat mowe neuer wholesome yeeld flower aboundance otherwise would besides corne euer safely kept eare garnercorne better kept eare garner take much lesse pu rifaction whence come great cornmasters hoarder corn want roome lay corne thresh vp oldest store keepe chaffe till haue occasion vse mind whilest lye therein euer keepe sweet certaine rule nothing greater preseruer corne owne chaffe except care selfe nature hauing first placed necessitie must euer safest therein wherefore would haue good husband bring corne home barne first let rest three weekes moneth least time haue taken full sweat thresh itbad thresh sweating corne occasion shall serue herein also noted shall thresh time sweating danke soft mean grind make good flower except dried also held good profitable especially dried anie heat sunne yeeldeth husbandman garner proper barly oates rye sort pulse wheat tender graine selfe naturally apt heat putrifie kept close together great thicke heapes therefore wiser farmer doe vse spread wheat thinne better middest often load drie wheat mingle one millet made cleane coolenesse millet wheat vvill kept vermine taking manner heat occasion requireth millet vvill easily sifted wheat meanes sieue keeping said meale must make mass drie lumpes cummin salt powned lay middest meale appeare palmerwormes bred corne like vermine ouerheating must dust sieue spread abroad leaue sunne great heat euen vntill euening become hot thus sunne hath beene made verie cleane carrie vp againe highest garner haue thus vnnaturall heat thereof cease killed wheat coole danger former ouerthrow furthermore concerning fanning corne husbandman must beware least beguiled measurer yet measure seeing tricke haue either powring corne presse downe hand else strike measure knee cause corne run closer together may haue better measure craftie shift second measuring answerable vnto first although speake onely fanning vvhich two kind one fan loose clothes like sailes turned swiftly gathereth vvind disperse french whose soyle frequent vvith wheat little respect vse graines resort betterknowing husband whose opinion seres diuers later writer agree shall vnderstand rierie excellent graine pleasant sauourie warme drie ground especially red sand clay much mingled therewith grow clay richer better corne larger prouided mould loose gentle asketh many earings wheat doth must euer sowne one selfesame time yet ground thing good selfe vvill grow well ynough one earing prouided sowne ground pea reaped yeare pea reason running ground smothering weed good sleight manuring land rie verie quicke growth sprout would drowne rie would hardly grow therefore greatest care must faire season drie mould contrarie kill maslin maslin called latines metellum one kind corne mixture wheat rie white corne vvhich latines call far adoreum euen shall declare rie sort thes two kind corne mingled sowne gathered threshed together maslin delighteth mixt kind earth tillage consisting fit wheat bread made maslin one best sort aboundantly cropping gathering maslinto crop gather maslin blend corne shall euer doe soone see rie begin open turne eare downeward towards earth albeit wheat seeme little greenish root nothing neere doe affirme fine meale called french semole gros e slimie iuice digested without difficultie thereupon injurious haue need fine attenuating nourishment certaine great nourishment also bread made whereof hath steeped time vvater afterward brayed husked end dried againe sunne ground somewhat grosly made kind grosse meale embling verie much vvhereof sometimes vvoont made papmeat sometimes mixt meatbroth sometimes panade vvithall meat say truth doe nourish great deale profit health bodie much ingender thicke clammie gros e juice verie hurtfull subject vnto obstruction vnto stone grauell turkiewheat tvrkiewheat called rather indian wheat came first westindies turkie thence france sowed otherwise pleasure cause admiration strange thing frenchman themselues doe admire make much account sowne verie carefully manner field must diligently tilled according sort earings vvhich woont bestowed vpon ground afterward toward end march time sunne beginneth affoord hot comfortable beames franker freer sort said wheat must steeped water two whole day done keepe till earth receiue prettie showres vvhich happening presently open earth vvith sharpe stake along streight line equall sufficient distance cast euerie one hole foure fiue graines vvheat close earth againe vvith foot sort fill set vvhole field corne earth fat seed full well ed faile sprout within seuen day ready mow within fortie day two moneths three moneths furthest foure moneths sooner later according goodnesse ground power sunne say earlier hot place good ground lyeth open vpon sunne late cold ground leane place hath like temperature vvheat hath somewhat hot may easily gathered sweetnesse bread made thereof meale thereof vvhiter made wheat bread made thereof grosse thicke close lymie substance sort nourishment made thereof likewise grosse apter ingender obstruction vvher ore dearth vvheat famine doe force compel sow turkishwheat make bread thereof doe better mingle flower vvheat vse selfe alone throughout france abounding vvithout comparison foresaid turkiewheat must sowne manner ground refuseth grow vvhether grauelly quality vvhatsoeuer especially aprill hot place somewhat later cold better corne mingled corne countrie vvheat may made grosse meale euen grain called furmentie better without comparison millet imployed meatbroths panades papmeats also make cheese butter meat pleasant ynough much loading charging stomacke notwithstanding windie therein excessiue pea beanes goat wheat typh wheat yet remaining two sort wheat latines call trag cerealis typha cerealis whereof dioscorides galen doe make mention typh wheat verie like rie doth make verie blacke bread verie vnpleasant also old though otherwise verie pleasant new baked manner rie goat wheat verie much vnlike vnto th graine called furmentie saue onely meale yeeldeth bran without comparison maketh fitter bread loosen bellie feed nourish wheat much seene france therefore meane make longer discourse thereof manner marchcorne chap xviii barley vve haue thus largely spoken wheat corne remaineth vve consequently speake manner pulse ordering husbanding vvhereof speake generall like vnto graine going namely gathering stone manuring giuing first second third ea ing also clodding sowing harrowing mowing differing notwithstanding thing namely nature therefore best make particular description thereof especially barley howsoeuer sleight vse france great profit vine plentie wheat kingdome aboundeth yet country best respect especially england vvhere greatest sort doth grow make beere thereof good excellent french wine pleasant wholesome therefore speake first barley cording opinion french husbandman vvhich held authenticall barley must sowne leane drie small ground else ground verie fat throughout doth bring downe diminish fatnesse ground mightily cause either cast ground verie far force goodnesse vvhereof shall able hurt lea e ground vvherein man sow thing else well must sowne ground hath two earings country moneth october countrie fifteenth day aprill according common prouerbe george day must sow barley lay oat away ground fat leane ground must sowne sooner laying raine much according prouerbe wheat must sowne barley dust barley cannot endure great store moisture selfe drie open cold againe barley sowne moist place much watered vvith rainewater doth easily canker turne darnell oat manner ordering giuen barley called mundified barley chaffe thereof falleth presently cleaueth vnto corne doth common barley perceiue somewhat ripe must mow sooner corne hath brittle stalke straw verie apt breake verie drie corne weakely inclosed vvithin huske doth easily selfe fall vnto earth hence also becommeth easie thresh shake graine corne mowne good let earth lye ydle yeare else manure throughly take away euill qualitie remayning left behind bread deere yeare vsuall make bread barley vve shall declare hereafter better poore people rich yet one point praised much good wholesome haue gout assured truth vvhereof found rather experience reason notwithstanding much barley galen vvhether bread papmeat p isan mundified barley otherwise imployed doth coole yeeld thinne kind nourishment somewhat cleanseth bodie respect may profitable haue full humour subject distillation falling downe vpon mint made barlie certaine kind drinkemundified barley vvhich commonly called aptisane meat good sicke person called mundified barley th good vvife farme may make sort take barley well cleansed husked boyle till burst till become like vnto papmeat beat morter haue done straine verie fine strayner put vnto sugar juice sweet almond poppieseed melon lettuses according occasion shall offered else take best newest barley put mortar cast vpon warme vvater vvere wet make swim afterward beat gently vvoodden pestell sort huske couereth may forced chafe betwixt hand may free quite huskes afterward drie sunne vvhen haue done take handfull said barly put pot vvhich may fill halfe filling vp halfe vvater let boyle little little vntill time burst become like papmeat let run linnen cloth straine juice thus much french opinion barleyhow barley ought bee sowne come true knowledge thereof opinion better experienced shall vnderstand barley ought sowne vpon best richest best husbanded ground haue although grow soyle whatsoeuer vvell husbanded extreame cold moist yet better earth sow better larger corne vvhen groweth much seruiceable vse shall please imploy barley groweth stiffe clayes best large white full like bunting beake growes mixt soyle second best groweth sand vvorst barley asketh greatest tillage graines must euer lye loose gentle earth therefore hath least ought haue full foure earings sowne fertile rich clayes must first fallowed later end april stay till may ground may drie arder fallowing must cast downe ground say furrowes must turned downe ridge ridge left open earth must receiue seasoning midmay shall manure iune shall giue second earing called sommerstirring ardor shall set vp land shall plow furrow vpward toward ridge land closing vp opened lapping manure earth wise thereof vncouered august shall giue third ardor earing vvhich called foyling cast land downe againe vvhen fallowed ardor one best especially destroying weed thistle october shall giue fourth ardor earing vvhich called winterridging ardor shall euer set vp land againe sommerstirring march aprill following shall sow touching manner sowing stiffe clayes shall first make seedesman cast seed ouer land sufficient manner shall thinke meet taking plow beginning furrow shall cast land downeward ouer seed till haue plowed land left onely ridge open holding plow croswise ouerthwart ridge shall close ridge draw mould shall make seedesman cast another cast two seed vpon ridge onely harrow woodden toothed harrowes manner sowing called sowing vnder furrow whereas haue shewed plowing land must first cast downe land ridge vp foyle downe lastly set vp whole winter following shall vnderstand best orderliest husbanding land breedeth greatest plentie mould couereth manure closest maketh soonest rot earth yet notwithstanding much barley tender graine may meanes indure cold vvet find land doe lye flat water cannot descend either choaketh keepes vvet shall set vp land cast downe ardor till haue brought conuenient height vvater may haue free passage contrarie part vvhen land lye high shall cast furrowes downeward vntill haue brought lownesse vvhich shall conuenient vvhen haue done shall cast downe set vp againe order hath beene mentioned also another maner sowing barley vpon fertile rich ground vvhich called sowing vpon iunamesiunames sow barley ground vvhence haruest reapt barley must done sort soone haue reaped barley vvhich commonly august shall forthwith ground doe require manure much intend sow barley againe vpon soone haue manured immediatly ground hard shall plow either setting vp casting downe land shall require hard shall stay showre raine yet drier plowed better land come land thus plowed shall let lye till nouember shall plow againe earing shall meanes set vp cast downe land et lye till seedtime sow vnder furrow shewed barley vvhich groweth thus vpon iunames fairest vvhitest goodliest corne onely principall corne reserue seed therefore must haue great regard election barley thus sow vpon junames sowing barley vpon mixt earth hasellgrounds vvhich clayes sand clayes grauells mixt together shall husband ground poynts doe claygrounds onely shall differ time mixt earth must fallowed ianuarie sommerstirred may foyled august winterrigged october sowing shall sow vnder furrow aloft binding nature sowing sodaine raine fall drinesse follow would bake earth together corne vvould possible able sprout therefore said shall sow aloft say shall first plow beginning ridge setting furrowes vpward cast seed lastly harrow sowing barley vpon sandgrounds shall husband like vnto mixt earth onely shall giue ea ing say double foyling shall forbeare sow till whitsontide heat sand great vvill make corne verie swift growth ripen verie sodainely barley vvhat soyle soeuer sowne must exceeding vvell sleighted clotted stoned vveeded verie tender growth smallest clot stone keepe backe least vveed vvill choake barleybarley pretious estimation vvith vvhich know true vse thereof especially making mault vvhich made ale beere drinkes vvholesome excellent man bodie nation vvhich doth enjoy hath blessing preferre touching order making maltmalt sort first barley hath beene cleane vvinowed drest shall put cesterne fat made purpose sleepe vvater space three night draine vvater cleane let lye fat one night take forth fat lay vpon floore made either board plaster earth earth floore vvarmest best winter plaster floore coldest best sommer boarded floore betweene soone haue laied floo shall make great big coutch heape yard thicke better vvhich coutch shall make either long round square pleasure according quantitie corne shall thus lye coutch till see begin sprout put forth little white jag string vvhich called coming mal shall reane turn bringing vvhich outside midst vvas middest vnto ourside may come alike middest lieth warmest vvill euer come first soone see comed shall forthwith spread open coutch vpon floore laying aboue handfull deepe corne may coole sprout come forgetting euerie day space three vveekes vvithin three dayes three weekes least turne malt vpon floore twice thrice day least forbearing doe corne heat meanes akerspire vvhich sprout end loose heart graine make malt good nothing haue thus giuen full floore three weekes shall lay vvellbedded k lne vpon good haire cloth gentle fire drie best fewell make ire straw either wheat rie barley braken ferne good also go sse sharpe vvood vvorst leaueth sharpenes e smoake ill taste sauour vpon malt yet france kilnes made bricke vvith furnace carrie away smoake may burne fewell please vvithout annoyance neither dangerous casualtie fire ther plaine kilnes england place malt vvell dried shall hand rubbe well vpon kilne get come sprouting vvhich drying sticke vnto generall rule cleaner malt come snugger smoother lookes like barley prouided well malted better euermore marketable come nature drinke vp liquor vvhich malt mashed vvhen make beare ale meanes scant much proportion malt hath beene well rubbed reasosonable cleane shall shouell malt corne together put together close garner made purpose vvhere shall let lye least moneth six weekes vse ripen come make euer best yeelding malt please vse shall either winow trie skreene made wiers purpose grind brew occasion shall serue touching choyce best malt shal euer take made best cleanest corne without weedseeds like filthinesse yet haue oat better worse shall eye appeare bright white full cleane without come smell shal pleasant sweet sharpe smoake handling shal brittle apt breake kernell shall white meallie taste shall strong exceeding sweet graines shall champe mouth take forth presse betweene finger shall yeeld white juice like milke thicke luscious biting breaking hard vnapt bruise signe much barley vnmalted malt great deale lesse profit barley thus excellent making drinke good also bread french maner maketh bread thereof simple selfe indeed bread least nourishing vnsauourie mix graine wheat rye pea bean one maketh verie good wholesome bread vsed england hindseruants adding bushel bushell pea one pecke wheat another rie laying strong l uen scalding meale well take away strong smell pea sure verie strong wellrelished bread wholesome man shall labour hard found experience england place barley boyled water till breake giuen eat whilest sweet best food feeding fatting swine sort whether brawnes porkets baconhogges also farteth horse verie sodainely fat indure labour light corne hinder end barley excellent seeding sort poultrie capon hennes turkies geeese else strayeth farmer yard house leuen made cleane barleymeale milke best food cramming sort poultrie many vertues barley none greater vse alreadie rehearsed oatsoats notwithstanding grow amongst wheat barley without sowne euill vnprofitable thing notwithstanding profit comming feeding great cattell also men time necessitie deserue proper conuement kind husbanding loue sowne leane place drie well aired haue beene alreared twice eared februarie march later craue vvatering grow fairer fuller set must gathered presently rie barley although oat vsed make bread except time great dearth notwithstanding doe beat morter doe make meale thereof called oatmealeoatmeale vvhich boyled either alone else flesh vse manner panade physitians judgement oatmeale made doth feed verie vvell good grauellgrauell difficultie vrine truth vvhereof referre britaines ange ines vse effect boyled alone making pleasant woont put vnto cowesmilke goatsmilke juice sweet almond sugar flemmings vse make papmeat thereof loue exceeding vvellwater distilled oat muscouites distill water oat vse want wine water heateth maketh drunke lesse wine thus much french opinion oat vvho indeed halfe knowing much excellencie graine come knowledge haue full proofe triall thereof shall vnderstand graine lesse worth estimation questionlesse may much lesse banished commonwealth much none grow shall know oat grow soyle whatsoeuer either fertile barren hot cold drie moist doth aske much labour fertile soiles wil grow one earing namely seedtime euer end march beginning aprill grow also graine wheate rye barley pulse best sowing barley pulse sow wheat rie would pill ground much make barren soone barren ground grow two arders three one midsommer another michaelmas third seedtime else michaelmas seedtime onely must sowne vnder furrow like barley loose mould two three arders aboue furrow fast earth hath one arder onely must well harrowed according strength mould say woodenteeth loose mould vvith yron teeth fast mould must cropt soone turne colour appeare little yellow else vvill shed graine loosest corne oat diuers excellent v men also cattell first oatmeale made sort soone oat haue beene thresht vvynowed shall lay kilne vvith soft fire drie verie vvell carrie milne either windmill watermill horsemill let miller cut hull meanes crush fine meale onely driue cleane kernell courser hull vvith fanne gentle vvind vvinnow emptie hull corne find cleane hulled passe mill againe vvynow againe thus doe till null cleane taken vvhich hull verie good prouander horse groat vvhich vsually called common course oatmeale excellent make porridge kind pudding sort papmeat panada whatsoeuer also excellent food sea boyled water otherwise vsed manner grauell oatmeale ground ine meale like corne maketh diuers kind verie good bread chiefely corne mixe fine meale oates wheat meale maketh verie daintie oatcake either thicke thinne great estimation knowne oates maulted mault barley make verie good mault mault verie good ale beere little sharpe made barley lastly oates food best may feeding horse fatting cattell also good seed sort pulleine especially goose swannes manner waterfowle take much pleasure therein millet millet know verie well dwell countrey bearne bigorre armignac hath beene steeped certaine time water would sowne either morning euening coole thereof light small moulded ground groweth grauelly ground also sand country wet moist anie case would sowne drie ground consist fuller earth marly neither must sowne spring requireth heat wherefore may conueniently sowne end moneth march else somewhat later may enioy benefit dew long time putteth husbandman anie great charge little seed sowe great deale ground soone sowne must pressed downe hurdle wicker well laden keepe heat sunne springing vp thereof otherwise seed would grow vp drie away veh mencie heat sunnebeames notwithstanding would oft verie well weeded ooting vp manner ill weedes especially blacke millet soone may spied peeping forth earth operation sunne corne doe shew must pluckt vp hand laid sunne afterward drie lastly shut vp place may kept thus ordered lasteth longer anie manner corne millet doth good vnto field wherein gathered respect namely wormes hurt corne shall sowne presently anie whit seeing leaue graine sowne cleaue straw millet time dearth vse make bread millet vnpleasant ynough especially setled inhabitant gasco gne campaigne doe vse pappemeat made millet milke pleasantest taste well bread pappemeat made millet small nourishment besides make obstruction millet cold first degree drie third millet fried salt flower camomill put bag doth serue paine collick wringings bellie keepe purgatiues rubarb agarick yea flesh also rottennesse corruption good burie millet sesame sesame would sowne blacke ground somewhat rotten moist groweth also sandie fat grauellie ground mingled ground verie fruitfull euen le e millet pannicke true good householder needeth trouble braine much sowing seeing apt make ground altogether barren yet good nothing except oyle pressed cake liquorish woman vse make mealeoyle cake sesame must sowne midst summer while time continue drie raine looked long time raine doth hurt sowne cleane contrarie plant reioice raine sowne oyle pressed seed sesame doth neuer freeze lightest oyles yet mixt wine aquavitae sinketh bottome account made graine nourishment giuen ouercome stomacke hardly digested oylie matter lentil lentil must sowne two time autumne commonly especially france cold country spring time while moone encreaseth vnto twelfth thereof either small little mould fat fertile ground flower destroy spoyle themselues much moisture putting farre earth end may grow speedily greater must mixt drie dung sowne foure fiue day haue beene laid rest dung sowe keepe long continue mingled ash put pot wherein oyle preserues haue beene kept sprinkled vineger mixt beniouin lentil howsoeuer auncient philosopher estimation hard digestion hurtfull stomacke filling gut full wind darkening sight causing fearefull dreames withall nothing good boyled flesh fried oyle fasels fasels grow stubbly ground rather great deale better fat ground tilled sowne euerie yeare sowne betwixt tenth october first nouember else march pul e ground hath beene eared eleuenth nouember must sowne haue beene steept water make grow mose easily large sowne alwaies ripen gather make far ground sowne accustomed beare much fruit keepe long time swell grow greater boyling good pleasant tast vnto n mouthes true windie hard digest yet notwithstanding apt prouoke vnto venerie boyled powdred ouer pepper galanga sugar yet specially boyled fat milke vntill burst mind take away windinesse eat mustard caraway seed haue beene bitten horse take fasels chew apply chewed vnto greene wound young gentlewoman striue beautifull may distill water fasels singular good end purpose lupine lvpines craue great husbandrie good cheape doe good ground anie seed vineyard arable ground become leane stand stead verie good manure vnto likewise want dung may sowne ground stand need dunged haue put forth flower second time plowed vnder ground grow well leane ground tyred worne sowing may sowne anie ground especially stubbly ground tilled sort soeuer sowne abide roughnesse ground negligence husbandman neither doe craue anie weeding well respect root single also hurt would die presently also bee labour lost farre infected wronged weed euen kill cause die cause manie sowe middest vineyard end may draw vnto bitternesse vineyard qualitie familiar vnto best agree notwithstanding may sowne deepe flower made account kind pulse stand need laid vp garner rather vpon floore smoake may com vnto moisture take grow full wormes eate vp make sprout remaining doe good must gathered raine drie weather would fall cod lost lupine good feed ox winterwherefore lupine good must sunneshine lupine stampt laid vpon nauellwormes little child kill wormes little child decoction thereof doth prouoke termes woman taketh away obstruction sight reason whereof manie doe wish taken else ground well manured eared two earings although stubbly ground seated low bottomes vvhither fat substance higher part doth descend notwithstanding earth must li ed cut small clod broken sowne albeit amongst sort pulse doe little vvaste strength juice earth notwithstanding desire vvell deepe couered vvithin earth must diligently vveeded time peepe earth fruit vvill much coddes farre tenderer may sowne two time yeare autumne vvhere strong ground beanes great spring especially countrie vveake light ground beanes small common size vvhich sowne autumne worth hindes let say rather eat huskes stalkes beanes sowne due time beanes themselues three moneths old yeeld fruit haue greater better stored graine time soeuer sowe must haue speciall regard sowe fifteenth day change moone th ter loaden much assailed little vermine moone new day sowne must steepe lee oliues water nitre end may beare fruit easie boyle subiect eaten weeuils larkes must likewise reape pull vp new moone day leaue ayre drie thresh full moone afterward carrie garner thus ordered vermine breed againe proue profitable planted sowne good ground well dressed tilled fatted manured vvhich said ground sowne yeare following wheat yeeld copious plentifull haruest much beanes doe fatten ground anie kind pulse would keep long must sprinkle salt water meane boile must bee sure keep salt saltwater doth harden must left cold aire cold also doth make harder boile keepe euen wormes must bee annointed rubd ouer oileoliue one another vntill time well liquored oile flower beanes notwithstanding pleasant delightsome smell doe hurt weake brainethe cause manie fooles beanes flower one easily carried away ouercome hereupon commeth passe great number fooles beanes flower thus much french experience beanes doth indeed concerne gardenbeane continually vse amongst husbandman therefore come profit true knowledge husbanding beanes shall vnderstand onely sowne rich stiffe ground verie fertile namely black blew clay earth oy little grow one ea ing onely would done beginning ianuarie vpon earth hath borne barly else vpon greeneswarth hath plowed long must plowed deep haue great furrow turned vp shall let lye till haue taken frost raine vpon next faire season soone valentine day shall sowe harrow weeding beanes purpose themselues swift growth outgrow weedes haue anie pea mixt amongst euer surest seed smother vp destroy sort weedes vpright growing better mowne sythes cut reapt hooke aske little withering soone cod turnes blacke stalke dryes vse principally prouander horse mixe barley wheat rie make bread hindseruants hunting running horse commonly vsed simply themselues else mixt wheat onely mixture barley rie good horse nature except cause physicall keepe soluble body forth gardenbeane good men eat boyled mixt butter vineger pepper want butter oyleoliue cod also verie good food boyled whilest greene tender lastly water distilled flower beanes good take away morphew spot men woman face small peason small pea lesse profitable fatting ground leane lupine true looke haue good store wellcodded must sowe fat warme ground temperate moist time februarie march sometime september increase moone yet hard endure hold winter cold alwaies desire full fruition sunne doe grow great deale fairer doe enioy accordingly also borne vp end stickes rather let fall flat ground creepe vpon must sowne thinne stalkes doe spread themselues anie one kind pulse verie subiect eaten within wormes yet eaten wormes better sowe whole sound cause preuent wormes may hurt hinder corne sowe peason first place true better growth prospering thicke grosse seed conuenient sowne especially laid water steepe therein night thereby grow easily lose part saltnesse steept meanes recouer naturall verdure againe must gathered decrease moone presently vpon ripe else drie vp fall swad earth wherein sowne standeth need one earing cich peason cich peason doe likewise grow fat moist place must sowne rainie time doe greatly load burthen earth cause neglected wiser sort husbandman notwithstanding sowe must steepe warme water day may grow put forth earth sooner greater haue grow fairer doe steepe cod nitrous water keepe passenger folke may gather eate ripe must water fiue morning together sunne rise water wherein haue beene steeped seedes wild cucumber wormewood dew within fiue day haue taken away bitternesse thereof practises likewise good vsed small peason beanes vse good slow performe act carnall copulation especially carrie away grauell breake stone also haue weake lung low weake voice also good melancholie doe cut troublesome thought cogitation put place thereof iollie conceit merrie moodes laid forth mooneshine encrease sunne rise must sprinkled oyleoliue afterward steeped warme water soften lastly boyled eaten way vse rather suppe vp broth made rootes parsley eare peason small cich peason small cich pea called latines cicercula must sowne fat place moist time ianuarie februarie doe lesse harme field anie pulse part neuer come profit flower cannot abide drowth anie strong southerne windes time leaue flowring great wild tare bitter fetch great wild tare bitter fetch doe desire leane place ar moist sometimes putting forth freely growing much ouerthrow themselues may sowne autumne end ianuarie moneth februarie march sowne moneth would hurt cattell especially ox troubling braines fetch two seedtime fetch first sowne feed cattell fifteenth day september second februarie march make bread eat mixt corne may sowne vntilled ground better sowne ground haue three earings seed loueth dew therefore must sowne two three houres sunnerise moisture thereof spent consumed either wind sunne must alone sowne must also couered verie day night come vpon wet little couered would quickly become corrupt putrified ground wherein sowne needeth anie one earing sowne needeth weeding anie case must sowne fifteenth day moone otherwise snailes annoy like manner must sowne neere vnto anie vine orchard anie place tree growing draweth vnto iuice plant neere yet fetch doth make ground leane rather fat appeareth soone fetch taken away field may peason millet anie sort pulse sowne panick would sow panick must make choice light grauellie sandie stonie ground one situate amongst hill top hill yet whereas little resort water hot nature groweth putteth forth easily millet must sowne summer groweth speedily may mowen within fortie day sowne inhabitant gascoigne make bread thereof verie vnpleasant verie short apt c umble away euen like ash sand perigordians frie butter oyle others eate milke meatbroth fenugreeke cummin mustardseed sowing fenugreeke must make choice ground would fetch must cut second time seeing first done thicke small deepe serue graine couered aboue foure finger would able sprout spring vp therefore plough harrow must goe lightly ouer meale fenugreeke brimstone nitre doth take away freckle face mingle fourth part seedes cress vineger proue singular remedie falling haire called tinea boile honied water putting thereto swine grease resolue swelling testicle hand foot vnder eares profitable wrench ioints decoction thereof drunke oftentimes doth infinite good haue beene troubled old cough likewise vlcers breast distillation rhewmes falling vpon eye must wet clothes decoction seed apply vnto browes cummin mustardseed wee haue spoken second booke medick fodder snaileclauer either anie pulse feeding agreeable precious feeding beast snaileclauer called french sainct foin may seeme spring earth speciall fauour god onely nourishing fatting heards cattell also serue physicke beast sicke respect called latines medica call burgundie hay burgundians beene alwaies verie carefull sowing tilling hearbe inhabitant picardie call foinasse manie haue giuen name great trefoile howsoeuer name goe benefit gras e great euerie casefull husbandman ought continually reserue better part ground bee sowne therewith make choice therefore sowing growing great store gras e euen ground verie cleane fat easie plowed hath three earings sowne also hath beene well dunged well harrowed digged delued rather decrease moone plowed plough beginning worke iune afterward august october december februarie end weedes ground may bee sufficiently killed well heate summer cold winter haue made ground well pleasing fit industrie beginne sow end aprill new moone toward latter end day watered dew night spring speedily easily earth sowne heat day would burst continually would come small effect profit must bee niggardly sowing much seed sow much thicke grasse grow neither grow grasse also profit grow rise thereupon good householder soone sowne must harrow euerie manner way longwaies broadway ouerthwart harrowe rake wood set thicke teeth yron vtter enemie yron afterward must water gently first time water forcibly aboundant store water driue seed one side field yet must water september vnto end aprill good cut downe fiue sixe time first yeare proportionably yeares following endureth ten yeares yea thirty pliny sayeth without standing neede sowne againe fit time cut downe may iune iuly august new moone meane time shall let lye vpon heapes longer day meadowes stay long time would raise hear vvould smother kill whatsoeuer vnder keeping euer growing againe wherefore good carrie elsewhere drie assoone possibly may bee stirring euerie day day day againe must let cattell feede neere vnto grasse much tooth onely verie breathing also noysome vnto greatly afterward becommeth either barren else dieth presently must bee giuen greene cattell eate least make sicke reason moisture heat therein must stay till drie giue eate also small quantitie grasse begetteth store blo much eating thereof would strangled therewith good husbandman must carefull gather reserue seed snaile clauer sow vvhen shall bee requisite must bee gathered first yeare beareth reason weakenesse following moneths iune iuly soone huskes wherein seede contained shall appeare drie seed themselues turned yellow mixt prouander mixt prouander must sowne fat well manured place haue beene twice eared verie good sowne pilde barley sometimes consisteth barley oat fetch fenugreeke vvhich let grow hand ouer head cut afterward either greene ripe make fodder cattell winter rice sow rice may doe like proue rather worke curiositie profit rice commoditie properly belonging growing amongst indian whence also brought hither vnto v france therefore sowing rice either white red chuse place verie moist case haue amongst arable ground chuse field leane foule nothing well clensed light weake yet euen may conuey little brooke gutter water eare ground thrice meane sow rice haue thus plowed ouer thrice sow rice therein must first steepe one whole day water soone haue sowne draw littlebrooke along suffer continue fiue whole moneths depth two singer perceiue blade begin shoot forth eare knowing also flowreth seedeth instant double quantitie water keepe fruit blasting spoyling otherwise order thus shall onely reape great quantitie rice may also sow three yeres together one another without giuing rest ground yet last yeare bee lesse fruitfull former yea shall make field fat frolicke better plight cleaner weedes cleaner noysome beast yea furth r may sow therein three yeares one kind graine wh ther wheat meslin whereof shall repent time haruest shall find faire profitable one inconuenience rice causeth ill aire reason aboundance water craueth space fiue whole moneths recompence withall proueth verie profitable food sustenance thereof made pottage thereof also bread made either rie mille three together true much giuen make obstruction restraineth flux mightily cause haue great loosenesse body vse oftentimes especially parched boild cowes milke wherein many little riuer haue bin quenched boyle milke adding therto sugar prouoke vnto venerie many thinke maketh fat seeing according physitians digested stomach verie hardly must need nourish little possibly make one fat indeed may said rather puffe vp make fat hempe hempe must sowne fat well dunged ground watered little brooke else fl moist country much labour ploughing hath beene bestowed fatter ground thicker barke pilling must sowne march gathered seed ripe afterward dried either sunne wind smoake laid water bee watered pilling may easily depurt stalkes afterward vsed making rope cloth labour trauaile well beseeming fit woman opinion french generall opinion better experienced rich ground spoken sow hempe must bee taken rich stiffe blacke clay clay although beare hempe yet put forth much bunne little pilling indeed hempe groweth therein good nothing therefore best ground sow hempe richest mixt earth whose mould driest loosest blackest quickliest ripe little earing namely two ardor vvould october first last march best conuenient time sowing hempe must bee exceedingly well harrowed clotted mould must bee made small dust seed verie tender first sprouting gotten aboue earth ou groweth weed whatsoeuer owne nature doth choake destroy whence come hempe neuer needeth weeding must bee diligently carefully kept tended first appeare aboue earth bird seede sweet much desired small bird without great diligent care leaue earth best time gathering hempe acording common custome housewiues saint margarets day towards latter end iuly particularly shall vnderstand best pulling hempe pill soone doth begin turne yellowish leaues hang downeward looking vnto earth seed seed looke blacke bee readie shed hempe must euer bee pulled vp rootes first spr ad thinne vpon earth afterwards bound vp bundle call bayts must bee c rryed water ripen water running streame best standing pond worst yet must bee done great heed hempe poysonous doth onely infect water doth also poyson much fish hempe must lye three dayes three night couered water must bee cleane washt water afterwards brought home dried either sunne vpon kilne bee housewiues either sloath want conuenient place water doe ripen hempe vpon ground suffering lye least fifteene night vpon taking dewes fall morning euening raine ripeneth prouided bee turned euerie day manner ripening good besides vnkindly doth oftentimes cause hempe bee rotten also maketh hempe blacke foule doth neuer make white cloth ripening drying hempe shall brake brake made wood purpose labour would euer neere bee done sunneshine braking hempe shall swingle beate heckle intend haue verie fine cloth shall first heckling beate againe heckle finer heckle spinne warpe lastly weaue thus much hempe vsed make cloth withall shall bee preserued cordage roper shall onely ripening pill either sell imploy hempe seed verie good make hennes lay many eggesthe seed hempe make hen lay egs depth winter greatest coldnes many doe burne thickest rootes male hempe burnt made powder make gunnepowder iuice decoction greene herbe strongly strained powred place earthwormes doth cause come forth likewise dropt eares causeth worm beastes shall bee gotten thither come presently wee haue learned fisherman wile doe take wormes serue hooke hempe seede must neither bee eaten drunke sendeth vp many fume vnto braine cause ake therefore woman greatly transgresse rule physicke giue bruised seed drinke troubled falling sicknes headach thing wondred hempe seeing two sort male female yet female beareth seed male line line must bee sowne ground riseth great profit followeth caused reason seede impaireth sort ground verie much cause must bee sowne verie fat ground one also reasonably moist case ground lineseed sowne must bee curiously handled clensed manifold earings plowed turned ouer oft long become like dust furthermore good huswife must carefull line growne free weed vsing wind called oft end gathering seed beating beetle heckling spinning filth may remaine among tow must gathered ripe colour groweth yellow layd vp drie place may bee defended raine dew vtter enemy vnto drie must thresht soone may end mouse eat wooden mallet get seed presently shalbe caried water change moone may lie therein three foure day iuly august till become soft tender end pilling barke thereof may easily seperated stalkes making cloth drawne water must bee laied heape round two three fadomes broad loading aboue boords stone spred sunne end may drie better finest line without seed notwithstanding bee least lower growth rest best soft fine manner silke whereas long thicke also rough boysterous spinningto make white threed shall make verie fine white sowing threed sine flax sort let watered running water fiue six day iuly august change moone soone drawne water spread sunne may drie neuer casting heapes laid vpon heapes comming water may take heat pressed downe end doth become blacke turneth darke obscure colour line hath receiued braking first hackling shall take strickes platting plat three make good bigge roule thereof put smooth round trough made purpose manner beate hempe shall beate flaxe till handle soft silke vnplat strickes againe heckle second heckle must bee much finer first done plat vp strickes againe beat second time vnplat heckle third time finest heckle bee gotten spinne ow make yarne either lawne holland combricke finest sister thred bee sowed hurds doe fall heckle shall haue great diligent care keepe light loose reason much beating bee exceeding soft apt clotter together abide lumpes drawing thred handle woollie yet bee well assured first hurds shall make exceeding fine mydling second fine lynnen third pure good holland many labour bestowed vpon fla ce alreadie rehearsed consisteth whole art huswife yet herein way bee noted euer beate flaxe shall bestow great drying letting stand seuerall time least foure twentie houres within aire fire beate drying causeth breake seed lineoyle linseed may presse oyle neuer cold vsed physitions painter many sort workemen singular good soften hard thing paine hemorrhoides chape tumour fundament called condylomata washed rosewater reth burning maruelous good plurisies old heateth procureth vomite nauets turneps nauets turneps delight light fine would sad ground yet turneps grow better moist ground top side hill drie pettie ground sandie grauelly howsoeuer ground sowne must haue beene oftentimes turned cast harrowed dunged meanes onely grow well ground gathered thus prepared bring forth fairer corne turneps sowne twice yeare februarie august well manured ground may suffer haue gotten little growth put vp earth still grow aboue earth root would become hard full small little hole see nauets turneps second booke chap xix aduertisements concerning corne pulse wise prudent husbandman must plow groundes cut vine prune haue dealing tree eighteenth day nouember vnto seuen twentieth december sow corne soone stay sow winter neither doe euer sow corne grew fat soile whether bee wheat rie leane barren field rather sow corne fat fertile soile grew leane barren ground briefe sow well conditioned ground growne ill conditioned ground sowing seed see hand auswere foot standing vpon foot see right foot especially moued right hand doth moue sowing wheat must cast full hand handful sowing barely rie oat many kindes graine especially shut vp huskes millet pannicke rape seed must sowne cast earth onely three finger preuent frost may hurt corne sowne especially sowne cold ground subiect vnto frost must cast spread lime vpon said ground besowne else better mingle sixt eight part lime amongst corn meane sow sow together keepe seed eaten bird mouse pi yres water sow iuice ho seleeke according virgil aduice water wherein nitre hath beene infused cause peason beanes pulse tender easily boyled must lay day bee sowne water vvherein hath beene nitre dissolued else mingle amongst fowing dung nitre notwithstanding meanes vsed cannot yet well boyled put pot wherein boyling little mustard seed short time relent seeth peeces beanes sowne neere tree cause root drie wither beanes keepe long water sea water greatly furnished cause rome kind bread made account vsed men leauing food cattell else reproch fainthearted dastardly souldiers vtterly forbidden euer set valiant couragious fight small quantitie nutritiue part nourishment true many imagine vse barley bread doth make lesse subiect vnto gout contrarie aristotle saith problemes baker vse baking weakned thereby yet rest vse handle worke much barley stuffe thing leaue tried sequell oaten bread commended imploying oat way rob cattell due food prouander great argument famine also bread vnpleasant taste better vse oatmeale made oat freed huske haue said treatise pottage vsed either flesh time time lent bread made millet panicke common bearne gascoigne amongst vulgar sort also house great lord vse rather daintinesse sake want good stomach otherwise verie drie light easily crumbling fit drie vp stomach bodie moist pleasant tast new well baked especially eaten comming hot ouen tasteth eateth maruellous pleasant sweetnesse likewise country bread made account baker carry presently drawne towne cry hot millet bread hot become hard looseth grace bread made pure cleane meslin good eaten according mediocritie substance thereof sort many compare bread made similago old time best excellent wheat regard made bread made bran commeth mealebread bran hath flower taken commonly called meale bran better leaue hound sheepherds dog serue keeping watch house england place make great profitabe vse meale namely certaine bread call horsebread generall among shall find inne alehouse common harbour doth want excellent good wholesome horse boast bran naturally hot burning selfe breed many inflammation hot disease amongst horse yet certaine feed much trauelling horse good food well allowable labour time trauelling time rest good wholesome especially common worse sort must vnderstand two kind common horsebread first kind made branne chyssell onely knoden cold water without mixture meale mould seemeth onely bind chissell together otherwise would fall sunder kind bread take two bushells branne chissell adde vnto one bushell beane pea meale kneade vp water scalding hot moulded roule spelted beanes crusht brused east furthermore much difficult thing find commodity good property ground aire euery countrie good workeman shall fit plant vine vnto nature place country wherefore fat ertile ground shall set young store wood leaues morillion morlou tresseau pulceau small mould reasonable fat ground plant putteth forth little wood samoureau lombard beaulnois meanes defect want excesse superfluitie qualitie young plant vine shall supplied corrected nature ground sort manner two excess shall spring one meane well tempered thing point wished requisite growing sort plant furthermore may plant moist place young plant giuen beare tender grosse grape samoureau gouet mourlous pulceau cinquaine tresseau place ossed wind stormes must prouide plant kind vine woont bring forth hard grape sticking fast close vnto stalke contrarie shall haue accustomed beare tender grape place hot giuen mild drie country must plant vine fruit whereof woont lightly either raine dew rot samoureau gouet pinot blanke beaunoies moist place woont spoile perish drinesse country troubled haile hard large leafe able better defend couer fruit chap iii planted vine way making seed nurcerie except onely pleasure mind man cannot hinder iniurie himselfe making nurcerices vine besides tree doth grow sooner kernel doth plant also inconuenience namely vine growing knernels doth yeeld thing profit good vse indeed worke loue pleasure haue purse largely defray charge thereof able thereby sow seed strange countrie afterward raise nurcerie stock growne vp bee transplanted remoued better ground may graft thereon afterward againe remoue stockes grafted better ground also two yeares may reape fruit thereof woont great daintie enough yet new vineyard thus planted least durable others againe countrie wee doe trouble selues planting vine runne vpon tree sort man may easily see doe lombardie place neither yet raised vpon single double shadowing arboursvines fashion arbour neither yet vse creepe along spread themselues vpon elmes tree wine neuer proueth good well root tree corrupted maner falleth colewort also plant loueth hoi ed mounted high neither yet shadowed building timberworke higher stature perfect man chap iiii plant vine must learne wine earth beare purposed plant whosoeuer doth purpose plant vineshow trie wine ground best bea e must much trust vnto markes signes good ground ceclared set downe first see haue made trial wine ground best beare mindeth plant vine labour lost money cast away plant vine small increase nothing like aunswere content expectation thus may trie proue ground make pit ground meane plant two foot depth earth cast pit take clod put glasse full raine water verie deane mingle beate together earth water let rest vntill time earth haue made perfect residence setling bottome glasse easily perceiued cleerenesse glasse follow thereupon earth throughly setled tast water looke relish tast hath would wine therefore vine yeelding relished wine fittest planted therefore find therin grape trodenwhat time wine must worke together troden wine liquor must let boile worke together space foure twentie houres lesse according purposed wine longer worketh together grosser deeper coloured mightier lesse worketh together finer thinne subtile delicate likewise would haue strong mightie wine must time working couer fat som couer vapor thereof may breathe force strength spend drosse grosse part grape trodden shall haue iuice liquor yet left remaining shall bee carried presse bee pressed shall abide three foure stroke true thus pressed make le e pleasant therefore bee best hath beene boiled chap xxii containing certaine discourse way inuention nature faculty difference necessitie wine haue former booke large intreated bread difference thereof according vse wherein imployed namely nourishment man bodie manner ordering husbanding vine fruit commeth husbanding thereof wine shall seeme vnreasonable summarily wee discourse stand vpon necessitie nature faculty difference wine whereof make great account ordinarily drinking thereof end may come matterthe necessitie drinke seeing substance man bodie liuing creature subiect vitall heate continually working vnto perpetuall wast expending selfe nature prouident ouer owne workes hath giuen vnto put sort liuing creature incredible desire eating drinking end waste losse substance might bee repaired restored well bounded increase comming eating drinking otherwise naturall heate destitute food nourishment would quickly choked quenched substance euery liuing bodie threefold first consisteth spirit second humour third solide part three substance may possibly repaired solide substance solide nourishment could easily bee digested distributed throughout whole habite vniuersall masse bodie seeing solidnesse hardnesse grosenesse therof cannot needfull accompanied floting fluide liquor might stand steed wagon chariot conueigh carrie vp downe bodie ioine also thereunto fluent liquor hath without comparison greater power solide nourishment let hinder drying vp solide part temper heat otherwise vpon euerie light motion might euerie moment offend hurt losse continuall expence threefold substance end doth first bring old age afterward death doth grow iarre disagreement foure element vvhereupon whole bodie compounded framed vvhich element also notwithstanding may seeme vnited ioyned together certaine kind harmonie consent amitie inuiolable bond yet reason secret rancour mutuall disagreement happening contrarie quality doe warre one vpon another little little procure ruine dissolution vtter ouerthrow bodie consented frame compose physitions ouer besides acknowledge another cause expence nature bringing old age lastly death vvhich foreslowed kept eating drinking naturall heat vvhich feedeth vpon radicall moisture seated substance solide part vvhich moisture sooner dried vp wasted consumed foresaid heat much shorter course life radicall moisture continuall losse spirit repaired addition eating drinking life drawne forth longer terme wherefore nature carefull preseruation long continuance body liuing creature vvhich otherwise occasion aboue named vvould grow old perish houres taketh anie course eating drinking vvhich two meanes sustaine preserue much possible liues liuing thing eating let v leaue haue anie thing doe hauing spoken thereof former booke let v come second vvhich drinking common drinke liuing creature water old ancient history doe sufficiently testifie water first drinke men vsed generally throughout world wherewith contented themselues long time vse onely quenching thirst afterward vvhen voluptuousnesse seized vpon men appetite inuented set diuers sort drinkes wherefore hauing reiected water tastlesse vnsauourie thing haue place thereof coast country heat sunne might bring forth lead along grape vnto full ripenesse chosen wine excellent delightsome drinke others cold country whereas vine could grow haue either still continued drinking vvater fetched procured vvine place else haue prepared kind drinke comming neere measure vnto vvine vvhich delicatenesse thereof might reioyce heart gratifie tast whereupon stead vvater haue taken vp vse wine others beere ale cyder perrie others sort honied vvater vvater sweetened vvith sugar others drinkes pressed strained fruit decoction rootes france italie sicilie spaine country farre north greene raspe wine much containeth water wine nourisheth bodie little hard digestion moueth windinesse wringings belly cold temperature hence commeth old folkes cold moist nature haue weake stomackes receiue damage next vnto woman haue termes aright subiect pale swarth colour notwithstanding passeth away speedily vrine thinne annoyeth head reason profitable hot moist nature young folkes vvhich haue boyling burning bloud stomacke good state especially summer time respect dilayed sufficient quantitie vvater serue fitly like manner vvine called greekes oligophorum ague wherein wine may permitted saue onely somewhat hard digestion causeth many obstruction greene vvines together greenenesse astringent sowre without comparison hurtfull euery way respect hardly ripen concoct ingender obstruction passe slowly either vrine stoole notwithstanding become ripe time let alone cellar till raw crude part thereof ouercome owne proper naturall heat shall seeme exceed bound reason wee discourse somewhat freely verdure vvines end wee may able discerne find vvines way purchase naturally galen writeth astringent qualitie vvines separated remaining apart verdure goodnesse badnesse meanes either astringent else rough harsh strong mightie vvines neuer little tainted greenenesse presently become sowre altogether vnmeet drunke pressed grape scarce halfe ripe differ much greenenesse sharpenesse common veriuice concocted little little strong forcible heat contained crude raw matter end become ripe greenenesse little little diminished passing yeares continuance seruing rather rude homely people daintie delicate personage certaine greenenesse vvine fault vvines vvherein yet worst rest happeneth vnto vvines sometimes good commendable either kept long else hauing beene ill kept otherwise occasion lesse dispraiseable hurtfull vvithout comparison happeneth french wine weakenesse heat sunne comming short sufficient concoction become greene first originall growth greene reason greene vnripe grape whence pressed greenenesse happeneth vnto vvines good commendable hurtfull vnto men cannot redressed thereby making vvines vnfit employed vse either medicine sawces vvhereas borne ingrafted greene vvines suppressed digested naturall heat becommeth onely hurtfull cold moist constitution old folkes vnto strong iustie hot nature neither vnto accustomed trauaile auoid idlenesse shall find many harsh rough sowre vvines vvhich also greene like manner shall find greene yet rough course rough greene vehement astringencie doe close shut vp drie dull throat tongue part mouth whereas simply greene doe like coole onely rough harsh vvines much raw crude cannot concocted digested naturall heat weake yet close bind stomack occasion stay lux bellie wine simply greene doe like harsh rough astringent withall doe rather annoy stomacke membranous neruous part reason cooling propertie qualitie vvhich situate thinne subtile matter therefore apt pierce deepely part quality prouoking disquieting substance said part doth corrupt dissolue laudable temperature force constitution said stomacke said membranous sinewie part whereupon ensueth greene vvines doe part cause crudity wringings flux belly manifold obstruction liuer spleene besides disease called hypochondriake melancholie galen denieth vvines hard greene doe heat sowre rough harsh rellish doth actually consist meane matter participating waterie earthie element hard greene sowre relish doth consist earthie drie substance vvhich doth manifestly participate water moisture whereby may manifestly appeare neither one relish hath heat ruling cold tart harsh rough relish accompanied moisture sowre drinesse much vvines seldome consisting one onely simple pure relish vvines tast relish soeuer temperature hot drie must vnderstand sowre harsh vvines accounted cold else hot simply comparison indeed heat lesse vvines quickly soone drunk end aftersome continuance time otherwise opinion galen receiued betake themselues enough allow place one male eight ten female yet therewithall keepe bucke close shut vp lodging feare hurt wrong young one male conie contrarie nature manner buckes deuoureth young one true soone espied doe hath kindled must incontinently put hole male may bucke certain thing soone doe emptie deliuered young one euen soone full againe young sort bringeth forth young euery moneth yeare yea great young letteth take bucke continue second burden bringeth forth afterward due time fruitfulnesse cony hath become admirable vnto many haue vpon slender ground thought beleeued bucke shoold conceiue aud become great young aswell doe false altogether contrarie naturall course action generation seeing nature course ordained female amongst beast conceiue ing nder male young one growne somewhat great become able leaue dam shall carrie warren store therewith let grow wild otherwise keepe shut vp fast inclosed clapper dam become tame alwaies continue slumbring heauie like vnto continually shut vp clapper made purpose haue grosser vnpleasant flesh yet notwithstanding must beware put abroad warren old clapper cony either male female seeing haue free swing run abroad warren haue learned saue themselues danger violence offred fox wild beast would bee deuoured thereupon seemes better containe continue still accustomed clapper cony clapper sed col wort lettuses groundsell clarie succorie sowthistle arragon thistle cich pea oat barely bran mingled together like thing haue spoken heretofore country feed man bloud come sicke person let bloud manner feeding starke naught maketh flesh vnsauorie eating preiudiciall vnto health surely speake truth food man bind conie wholesome beast aboue desire freedome feeding make choice owne meat whence come tame conie nothing pleasant eat wild much ranker taste easie discerned chap iii cony warren ought handled ordered although hauing clapper necessarie storing warren againe againe haue said notwithstanding need one may leaue vse clapper without charge expences content himselfe putting certaine number cony male female warren haue sufficient store encrease young one true fruitfull plentifull encrease therefore warren soone stored accustomed warren become sauage strange lesse giuen engender thereupon commeth warren bring forth young one onely thrice foure time yeare kept houseclappers euerie moneth howsoeuer find profit furnish warren store later manner sufficient six dozen put nine buck hauing regard consideration still vnto buck spare time would take feeding shall otherwise hath alreadie beene mentioned yet notwithstanding besides manner feeding would haue great store cony vvarren sufficiently fed become fat good sowe acre ground two barly oat make haruest shall leaue vneaten must haue speciall care feed vpon good nourishment flesh like manner flesh partridge doth retaine smell sauour whereupon feed example iuniper vvaren full iuniper semblably thing see coniehole stopt hay straw like thing doe vnstop content selfe onely obserue gesse young one vvithin vvhich dam nourisheth manner doe time hath kindled vvhether house clapper vvarren shee shutteth stoppeth vp hole hay straw grasse shee gather together end bucke may find yong one goe hole vvhere hee come hee would eat vp young one thing assuredly vndoubtedly conceiued doe whether hole else goe forth feed stoppeth earth returne find mouth hole neuer little vnstopt selfe kill young one hauing taken opinion bucke gone thither cause good hunter neuer put ferret earth vvhose mouth see stopt feare disquieting dam causing kill young one true shee doth keepe hole euermore shut time shee knoweth young one growne great become strong ynough seeke meat runne others shee beginneth make little hole issue goe furthermore must thinke cony either male female doe time forget earth neuer farre howsoeuer say come haue memorie notwithstanding alwaies mindfull hole strayed wandered neuer farre reason likewise say good conie neuer die eartha good conie dieth alwaies earth must likewise coniecture conie taught nature afraid fox sheepe woolfe another case besides wild strange nature goeth hole mind runneth vpon nothing running thereby forgetting thinke vpon cony hole eating young one although bee mindfull owne earth yet hee taketh care neither casteth whit may find fall vpon belongeth another likewise doe take occasion whi regarding woont stop mouth thereof hath beene said furthermore must bee carefull round verdge conie warren secret obscure place shall find greatest suspition trackt vermine place trappes ginnes may take deuoure nei shall trappes bee made one fashion diuers fashion must bee hollow passable way called coffer trappes hutch fralltraps crush kill sodainely springtrappes snickle halter either bird beast also pitfall cat kind buzards crowes like breed great destruction warren well scar away hunting thereabouts also giue testimonie owner care diligence preseruing ground like incumbrance chap iiii difference betwixt themselues remoued plant hath alreadie enough beene said profitable speedie certaine growth therefore sooner able bestow pastime vpon master second way grow tree grow branch writhen buried earth vvhich happeneth cornegrounds vineyard seeing beare except continually husbanded tilled wherefore ground imploied beech mast vvood yeeldeth much profit stand house great stead seeing cannot way held
